original_table_html:
Product Brand average volume accounted for by its top 20% of consumers (%)
Soft drinks 64
Yoghurt - Refrigerated 60
Cat food - Dry 56
Dog food - Dry 54
Breakfast cereals 54
Yellow Fats 53
Canned Soup 53
Fabric softeners - Liquid 51
Detergents - Light Duty 49
Deodorants - Aerosol 48
Creme rinses and conditioners 47
Automatic dishwasher compounds 45
Deodorants - Roll on 44
Fabric softeners - Dry 43
Shampoo 42
Fabric Softeners - Aerosol 35
Average 50
summary_markdown: This data presents a comparative analysis of various product categories, detailing the percentage of brand volume attributed to their top 20% of consumers. The structure highlights a concentration of consumption within a small consumer segment across diverse product types. Soft drinks exhibit the highest concentration, with 64% of brand volume coming from their top consumers, followed closely by Refrigerated Yoghurt at 60%. Other categories like Dry Cat food and Dog food, and Breakfast cereals show a significant, though slightly lower, concentration at 56% and 54% respectively. As the list progresses, the concentration generally decreases, with products like Shampoo (42%) and Fabric Softeners - Aerosol (35%) showing less pronounced loyalty or reliance on a core group of heavy users. The overall average across all listed categories indicates that, on average, 50% of brand volume is driven by the top 20% of consumers, underscoring a common pattern of concentrated demand across these consumer goods.
